Chief Complaint: S/p PEA arrest during echo while admitted for presumed
   COPD admission to [**Hospital1 **] [**Location (un) 1415**].
   To [**Location (un) 1415**] with SOB, cough, thought to be COPD. Declined BiPAP. PEA
   arrest at noon on [**1-1**]. Given atropine, epinephrine, intubation and
   CRP with restoration of circulation. On levophed. CT torso showed
   spinal fracture at T11 with hemorrhage into canal. CT head clear
   despite right ear bleeding. Hypothesis is kyphosis/AS with fusion,
   lying flat and CRP -> fracture.
   24 Hour Events:
   - Spoke to Anesthesia about surgery (that Ortho. Spine agreed to).
   They feel risk very great, but likely less if wait after cardiac
   arrest.  Therefore will be important to assess functional status,
   clearly understand functional status prior to event, know what cortical
   function is like, discuss with daughter (Anesthesia happy to talk to
   her in a.m. - just call Anesthetist on service in a.m. in OR - x43000
   when daughter here or know that she's available).
   - No bowel movements
   - Will be repeat echo this a.m.
   - Need to discuss plan with Ortho Spine and Anesthetics.
   Allergies:
   Penicillins
   Hives;
   Sulfonamides
   Unknown;
   Bactrim (Oral) (Sulfamethoxazole/Trimethoprim)
   Rash;
   Vancomycin
   Rash;
   Last dose of Antibiotics:
   Ceftriaxone - [**2120-1-2**] 08:12 PM
   Levofloxacin - [**2120-1-2**] 09:59 PM
   Piperacillin - [**2120-1-3**] 12:00 AM
   Infusions:
   Midazolam (Versed) - 2 mg/hour
   Fentanyl (Concentrate) - 150 mcg/hour
   Phenylephrine - 0.5 mcg/Kg/min
   Other ICU medications:
   Propofol - [**2120-1-2**] 02:20 PM
   Fentanyl - [**2120-1-2**] 04:30 PM

   Other medications:

   RR (Set): 20
   RR (Spontaneous): 0
   PEEP: 10 cmH2O
   FiO2: 40%
   RSBI Deferred: PEEP > 10
   PIP: 44 cmH2O
   Plateau: 28 cmH2O
   Compliance: 33.3 cmH2O/mL
   SpO2: 100%
   ABG: 7.35/55/145/30/3
   Ve: 8.6 L/min
   PaO2 / FiO2: 363
   Physical Examination
   General Appearance: Very Obese, lying on back, intubated on assist
   Eyes / Conjunctiva: PERRL
   Head, Ears, Nose, Throat: Normocephalic, Endotracheal tube, no further
   right ear bleeding.
   Cardiovascular: Very distant heart sounds
   Peripheral Vascular: DP not palpable, radial 1+.
   Extremities: right hand and left foot cool; left foot and right arm
   warm.  Right arm erythematous.
   Respiratory / Chest: Expansion: Symmetric, Breath Sounds: Wheeze
   throughout.  Did not auscultate back
   Abdominal: Soft, Bowel sounds present, Obese, non-tender
   Skin:  Not assessed
   Neurologic: Responds to loud verbal stimuli, touching chest, Movement:
   Movement of neck and opening of eyes in response to verbal stimuli and
   tactile stimulation of chest. Sedated.
   Labs / Radiology

   Other labs: PT / PTT / INR:13.1/30.8/1.1, CK / CKMB /
   Troponin-T:825/21/0.04, ALT / AST:31/46, Alk Phos / T Bili:61/0.2,
   Differential-Neuts:83.0 %, Lymph:12.7 %, Mono:4.1 %, Eos:0.1 %, Lactic
   Acid:1.1 mmol/L, LDH:215 IU/L, Ca++:8.3 mg/dL, Mg++:2.1 mg/dL, PO4:2.5
   mg/dL
   Micro:
   Gram stain
 Endotracheal sputum [**10-29**] PMNs, 3+ GNRs, 1+ budding yeast
   Legionella antigen negative
   Blood cultures pending.
   Imaging: CT Torso [**2120-1-1**]:
   2. Massive disruption at the T11 level with distraction, hemorrhage
   into the central canal, massive angulation and vertebral body
   destruction.  Vertebral body destruction ivovles essentially the entire
   T11 body and the inferior aspect of T10.  There is extensive soft
   tissue pathology here.  While much of this is of high attenuation the
   suggestion of hemorrhage, and given the underlying bony ankylosis
   trauam is thought a possible diagnosis, infection and or pathological
   fracture secondary to tumor are myeloma are not excluded.
   2. There is no evidence of primary or secondary malignancy elsewhere.
   There are no findings suggestive of dissection or acute aortic
   pathology.  There are innumerable pulmonary nodules, many of which are
   ground glass in nature, possible infectious but non-specific.
   Echocardiogram [**2120-1-1**]:
   The left atrial volume is mildly increased. Left ventricular wall
   thicknesses are normal. The left ventricular cavity size is normal.
   Overall left ventricular systolic function is mildly depressed (LVEF=
   50 %). Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal.
   The aortic valve leaflets are moderately thickened. There is moderate
   aortic valve stenosis (valve area 1.0-1.2cm2). No aortic regurgitation
   is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened. Mild (1+)
   mitral regurgitation is seen. There is no pericardial effusion.
   CT Head [**2120-1-1**]:
   The ventricles and sulci are normal in caliber and configuration.
   Remnant contrast is seen within the venous and arterial system within
   the brain likely from prior done CT torso.  This lowers the
   sensitivity of the current study for small infarcts.  However no large
   infarcts, bleeds, or other acute processes are present.  No fractures
   are present.  The mastoid air cells and sinuses are well-aerated.  An
   ET tube is seen in the oral cavity.
   CXR [**2120-1-1**]:
   An endotracheal tube has been positioned with the tip about 5 cm above
   the carina.  There is diffuse density overlying the right base but this
   appears to be artificial.  The lungs appear clear with
   normal vascularity and the cardiac size is within normal limits.
   ECG: EKG [**2119-12-30**]: sinus tachycardia at 107, normal axis, q waves in
   II, III, aVF, no ST slevation or depression.
   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 76 year old female with a history of COPD on home oxygen,
   moderate to severe aortic stenosis and diastolic heart failure who
   presented to [**Location (un) 1415**] on [**2119-12-30**] with progressive dyspnea on exertion
   and cough productive of clear sputum transferred here after PEA arrest
   with evidence of unstable T11 fracture. Cord injury very likely, very
   poor surgical candidate, so will need to discuss this further with
   Ortho, Anesthetics and family. Otherwise treat respiratory
   failure/COPD.
   Unstable T11 fracture
   Spine is currently unstable. Cord involvement likely and recovery
   unlikely. Therefore intervention to improve stability and possibly to
   prevent pain associated with instability. Currently not withdrawing to
   painful stimuli in the lower extremities.  Ortho. Spine happy to
   operate. Need to evaluate and discuss further with Anesthetics and
   Ortho. Possible that delaying may improve prognosis with respect to
   anesthesia/procedure. Not clear that patient will tolerate lying prone
   for procedure. MRI not possible due to girth, so evaluation of spinal
   injury will have to be functional.
   - Consider MRI if possible
   - D/w Anesthesia and Ortho Spine then
   - D/w family whether or not operative management would be within the
   patient's goals of care
   - Log roll precautions
   Shortness of breath/Hypercarbic respiratory failure
   Patient with known COPD at baseline on home oxygen.  She initially
   presented with worsening dyspnea and cough.  She quickly progressed to
   hypercarbic respiratory failure.  CXR have been unremarkable but CT
   chest with multiple small nodules which could be infectious in origin.
   Concern for atypical pathogens given recurrent steroid use. Legionella
   is negative, therefore can stop levofloxacin coverage.
   - Continue solumedrol 80 mg IV Q8H
   - Continue albuterol and ipratropium
   - Continue mechanical ventilation for now
   PEA arrest
   Enzymes now trending down. Most likely etiology is hypercarbia/hypoxia
   given ABG at the time of her arrest.  Unclear how long she was
   pulseless but she had return of spontaneous circulation with one round
   of epinephrine and atropine. Relatively [**Name2 (NI) 11259**] enzymes leak consistent
   with relatively brief event. There are no EKGs from the time of the
   arrest in her paperwork.  She had a CT Torso which showed no evidence
   of pulmonary embolism.  She was not cooled post-arrest. Will evaluate
   cardiac function.
   - Echo this a.m.
   Hypotension
   Differential diagnosis is broad and includes sepsis, cardiogenic shock,
   obstructive shock, volume depletion, decreased preload secondary to
   mechanical ventilation and others. Patient is (still about) 5.5 liters
   positive since her cardiac arrest yesterday.
   - Echocardiogram pending
   - Fluid challenge now for resuscitation goals of CVP > 10, UOP > 30
   cc/hr, MAP > 60
   - Continue fentanyl and versed (instead of Propofol)
   - Check mixed venous oxygen saturation
   - Phenylephrine for pressor as needed
   Leukocytosis
   Contribution by PEA arrest, steroids, spinal fracture, but still need
   to be sensitive to history of MRSA basteremia.  Will hold off on
   Vancomycin for now given previous adverse reaction (consider linezolid
   if febrile or others signs of sepsis).
   - Follow
   Urinary Tract Infection
   Patient with ciprofloxacin resistent urinary tract infection on
   [**2119-12-31**].  Now on ceftriaxone day [**2-11**].
   - Continue ceftriaxone day [**2-11**]
   Anemia
   Hematocrit 28 on arrival from 36 on [**2119-12-30**]. Now stable at 29. Likely
   dilutional in the setting of fluid resuscitation post-arrest.  Also a
   report of mild gastrointesinal bleeding in the setting of lovenox
   administration.
   - Maintain active type and screen
   - Trend hematocrit
   - Guaiac stools
   - Transfusion goal > 25 in periarrest period
   Right Ear Bleeding
   Possible injury to tympanic membrane during resuscitation in context of
   anticoagulation.  Normal head CT at [**Location (un) 1415**].
   - Otoscopy
   FEN: Normal saline boluses for resuscitation parameters as above,
   replete electrolytes, has NGT for tube feeds.
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin
   Access: Right IJ placed, left radial arterial line
   Communication: Daughters [**Name (NI) 755**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11255**], [**Name2 (NI) 378**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11256**]
   Code:  Full (discussed with patient)
   Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   20 Gauge - [**2120-1-2**] 12:30 PM
   Arterial Line - [**2120-1-2**] 01:30 PM
   Multi Lumen - [**2120-1-2**] 03:00 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition:

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old female with a history of COPD, moderate to severe aortic stenosis, and diastolic heart failure who presented to the hospital with progressive dyspnea on exertion and cough productive of clear sputum. She experienced a PEA arrest during an echocardiogram and was resuscitated with atropine and epinephrine. She was intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation. Her condition is complicated by an unstable T11 fracture, cord injury, and possible infection.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's COPD is worsening, and she is at risk for respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient has a history of MRSA bacteremia and is at risk for developing sepsis.
3. Cardiac Complications: The patient has a history of aortic stenosis and may be at risk for cardiac complications such as cardiogenic shock or arrhythmias.
4. Neurological Complications: The patient has a cord injury and may be at risk for neurological complications such as paralysis or numbness.
5. Infection: The patient has a history of recurrent steroid use and is at risk for developing an infection, particularly pneumonia or urinary tract infection.
6. Hemorrhage: The patient has a right ear bleeding and may be at risk for further hemorrhage.
7. Hypotension: The patient is hypotensive and may be at risk for further hypotension.
8. Anemia: The patient has anemia and may be at risk for further blood loss.
9. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient has a history of mild gastrointestinal bleeding and may be at risk for further bleeding.
10. Delirium: The patient is sedated and may be at risk for delirium.

Plan:

1. Continue mechanical ventilation and monitor for signs of respiratory failure.
2. Monitor for signs of sepsis and consider antibiotics if necessary.
3. Continue cardiac monitoring and consider echocardiogram to evaluate cardiac function.
4. Monitor for signs of neurological complications and consider MRI if possible.
5. Continue to monitor for signs of infection and consider antibiotics if necessary.
6. Monitor for signs of hemorrhage and consider transfusion if necessary.
7. Monitor for signs of hypotension and consider fluid challenge if necessary.
8. Monitor for signs of anemia and consider transfusion if necessary.
9. Monitor for signs of gastrointestinal bleeding and consider endoscopy if necessary.
10. Monitor for signs of delirium and consider sedation if necessary.

 TRAUMA, S/P
   Assessment and Plan: This is a 76 year old female with a history of
   COPD on home oxygen, moderate to severe aortic stenosis and diastolic
   heart failure who presented to [**Location (un) 1415**] on [**2119-12-30**] with progressive
   dyspnea on exertion and cough productive of clear sputum transferred
   here after PEA arrest with evidence of unstable T11 fracture.
   .
   Unstable T11 fracture: Patient transferred for ortho/spine evaluation.
   Spine is currently unstable.  Currently not withdrawing to painful
   stimuli in the lower extremities.
   - ortho/spine consult on arrival
   - will obtain MRI if possible
   - will obtain anesthesia consult
   - will discuss with family whether or not operative management would be
   within the patient's goals of care
   - log roll precautions
   .
   Shortness of breath/Hypercarbic respiratory failure:  Patient with
   known COPD at baseline on home oxygen.  She initially presented with
   worsening dyspnea and cough.  She quickly progressed to hypercarbic
   respiratory failure.  CXR have been unremarkable but CT chest with
   multiple small nodules which could be infectious in origin. Concern for
   atypical pathogens given recurrent steroid use.
   - urine legionella
   - followup sputum culture from [**Location (un) 1415**]
   - continue ceftriaxone for coverage of UTI and will add levofloxacin
   back for atypical coverage
   - continue solumedrol 80 mg IV Q8H
   - continue albuterol and ipratropium
   - continue mechanical ventilation for now
   .
   PEA arrest:  Most likely etiology is hypercarbia/hypoxia given ABG at
   the time of her arrest.  Unclear how long she was pulseless but she had
   return of spontaneous circulation with one round of epinephrine and
   atropine.  She does have a slight elevation of her cardiac enzymes
   post-arrest.  There are no EKGs from the time of the arrest in her
   paperwork.  She had a CT Torso which showed no evidence of pulmonary
   embolism.  She was not cooled post-arrest.
   - trend cardiac enzymes
   - EKG on arrival
   - mechanical ventilation as above
   - holding anticoagulation given bleeding
   .
   Hypotension:  Differential diagnosis is broad and includes sepsis,
   cardiogenic shock, obstructive shock, volume depletion, decreased
   preload secondary to mechanical ventilation and others.  CVP 16 in the
   setting of PEEP of 10.  Patient is 5.5 liters positive since her
   cardiac arrest yesterday.
   - echocardiogram pending
   - fluid challenge now for resuscitation goals of CVP > 10, UOP > 30
   cc/hr, MAP > 60
   - switch sedation to fentanyl and versed from propofol
   - check mixed venous oxygen saturation
   - will use phenylephrine for pressor as needed
   .
   Urinary Tract Infection:  Patient with ciprofloxacin resistent urinary
   tract infection on [**2119-12-31**].  Now on ceftriaxone day [**2-11**].
   - continue ceftriaxone day [**2-11**]
   .
   Anemia:  Hematocrit 28 on arrival from 36 on [**2119-12-30**].  Likely
   dilutional in the setting of fluid resuscitation post-arrest.  Also a
   report of mild gastrointesinal bleeding in the setting of lovenox
   administration.
   - active type and screen
   - repeat hematocrit tonight
   - trend hematocrit
   - guaiac stools
   - transfusion goal > 25 in periarrest period
   .
   Right Ear Bleeding:  Likely related to anticoagulation and chest
   compressions.  No evidence of intracranial bleeding on CT head
   peri-arrest.
   - continue to monitor
   - ENT consult if worsening
   .
   FEN: Normal saline boluses for resuscitation parameters as above,
   replete electrolytes, NPO given potential surgical interventions.
   .
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin
   .
   Access: Right IJ placed, left radial arterial line
   .
   Communication: Daughters [**Name (NI) 755**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11255**], [**Name2 (NI) 378**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11256**]
   .

   return of spontaneous circulation with one round of epinephrine and
   atropine.  She does have a slight elevation of her cardiac enzymes
   post-arrest.  There are no EKGs from the time of the arrest in her
   paperwork.  She had a CT Torso which showed no evidence of pulmonary
   embolism.  She was not cooled post-arrest.
   - trend cardiac enzymes
   - EKG on arrival
   - mechanical ventilation as above
   - holding anticoagulation given bleeding
   .
   Hypotension:  Differential diagnosis is broad and includes sepsis,
   cardiogenic shock, obstructive shock, volume depletion, decreased
   preload secondary to mechanical ventilation and others.  CVP 16 in the
   setting of PEEP of 10.  Patient is 5.5 liters positive since her
   cardiac arrest yesterday.
   - echocardiogram pending
   - fluid challenge now for resuscitation goals of CVP > 10, UOP > 30
   cc/hr, MAP > 60
   - switch sedation to fentanyl and versed from propofol
   - check mixed venous oxygen saturation
   - will use phenylephrine for pressor as needed
   .
   Urinary Tract Infection:  Patient with ciprofloxacin resistent urinary
   tract infection on [**2119-12-31**].  Now on ceftriaxone day [**2-11**].
   - continue ceftriaxone day [**2-11**]
   .
   Anemia:  Hematocrit 28 on arrival from 36 on [**2119-12-30**].  Likely
   dilutional in the setting of fluid resuscitation post-arrest.  Also a
   report of mild gastrointesinal bleeding in the setting of lovenox
   administration.
   - active type and screen
   - repeat hematocrit tonight
   - trend hematocrit
   - guaiac stools
   - transfusion goal > 25 in periarrest period
   .
   Right Ear Bleeding:  Likely related to anticoagulation and chest
   compressions.  No evidence of intracranial bleeding on CT head
   peri-arrest.
   - continue to monitor
   - ENT consult if worsening
   .
   FEN: Normal saline boluses for resuscitation parameters as above,
   replete electrolytes, NPO given potential surgical interventions.
   .
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin
   .
   Access: Right IJ placed, left radial arterial line
   .

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old female with a history of COPD, moderate to severe aortic stenosis, and diastolic heart failure who presented to the hospital with progressive dyspnea on exertion and cough productive of clear sputum. She was transferred to the ICU after experiencing a PEA arrest during an echocardiogram, and is currently on mechanical ventilation.

The patient has a number of significant medical conditions, including:

* Unstable T11 fracture
* Hypercarbic respiratory failure
* PEA arrest
* Hypotension
* Anemia
* Urinary tract infection
* Right ear bleeding

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Elevated cardiac enzymes (CK, CKMB, Troponin-T)
* Mildly depressed left ventricular systolic function (LVEF=50%)
* Moderate aortic valve stenosis (valve area 1.0-1.2cm2)
* Mild mitral regurgitation
* Elevated troponin-T (0.07 ng/mL)

The patient is currently receiving a number of medications, including:

* Ceftriaxone for coverage of UTI and atypical pathogens
* Levofloxacin for atypical coverage
* Solumedrol for inflammatory response
* Albuterol and ipratropium for bronchodilation
* Fentanyl and versed for sedation
* Phenylephrine for pressor support
* Heparin for prophylaxis

Potential medical complications:

* Sepsis
* Cardiogenic shock
* Obstructive shock
* Volume depletion
* Decreased preload secondary to mechanical ventilation
* Respiratory failure
* Acute kidney injury
* Pneumonia
* Urinary tract infection
* Right ear bleeding
* Gastrointestinal bleeding
* Anemia
* Bleeding complications related to anticoagulation

Recommendations:

* Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results closely
* Consider obtaining an MRI of the spine to further evaluate the unstable T11 fracture
* Consult with orthopedic and anesthesia teams to discuss operative management options
* Continue to optimize the patient's respiratory status with mechanical ventilation and bronchodilators
* Monitor the patient's cardiac enzymes and troponin-T levels to assess for cardiac damage
* Consider adding antibiotics for atypical pathogens
* Monitor the patient's blood pressure and consider using vasopressors as needed
* Continue to monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and consider repleting as necessary
* Consider obtaining a CT scan of the head to rule out intracranial bleeding
* Monitor the patient's neurologic status and consider consulting with neurology team if necessary
* Consider obtaining a stress test to assess the patient's cardiac function
* Monitor the patient's nutritional status and consider adding nutrition support if necessary
* Consider obtaining a glycemic control plan to manage the patient's blood glucose levels.

   .

   known COPD at baseline on home oxygen.  She initially presented with
   worsening dyspnea and cough.  She quickly progressed to hypercarbic
   respiratory failure.  CXR have been unremarkable but CT chest with
   multiple small nodules which could be infectious in origin. Concern for

   - continue mechanical ventilation for now

   return of spontaneous circulation with one round of epinephrine and
   atropine.  She does have a slight elevation of her cardiac enzymes
   post-arrest.  There are no EKGs from the time of the arrest in her
   paperwork.  She had a CT Torso which showed no evidence of pulmonary
   embolism.  She was not cooled post-arrest.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 76-year-old female with a history of COPD, moderate to severe aortic stenosis, and diastolic heart failure who presented to the hospital with progressive dyspnea on exertion and cough productive of clear sputum. She was transferred to the ICU after experiencing a PEA arrest during an echocardiogram.

The patient's current condition is:

* Respiratory failure: She is mechanically ventilated and has a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 363, indicating severe hypoxia.
* Hypotension: Her blood pressure is 98/45 mmHg, and her central venous pressure (CVP) is 10 mmHg, indicating hypovolemia.
* Trauma: She has an unstable T11 fracture with hemorrhage into the central canal.
* Cardiac arrest: She had a PEA arrest during the echocardiogram and required atropine and epinephrine to restore circulation.
* Anemia: Her hematocrit is 28, indicating dilutional anemia due to fluid resuscitation post-arrest.
* Urinary tract infection: She has a ciprofloxacin-resistant urinary tract infection and is currently receiving ceftriaxone.
* Right ear bleeding: She has bleeding from the right ear, likely related to anticoagulation and chest compressions.

Potential medical complications that can arise from these conditions include:

* Respiratory failure: Pneumonia, ARDS, respiratory acidosis, and hypercapnia.
* Hypotension: Sepsis, cardiogenic shock, obstructive shock, volume depletion, and decreased preload secondary to mechanical ventilation.
* Trauma: Pneumothorax, hemothorax, and spinal cord injury.
* Cardiac arrest: Myocardial infarction, cardiac tamponade, and arrhythmias.
* Anemia: Gastrointestinal bleeding, transfusion reactions, and decreased oxygen delivery to tissues.
* Urinary tract infection: Sepsis, pyelonephritis, and kidney failure.
* Right ear bleeding: Meningitis, intracranial bleeding, and hearing loss.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Mechanical ventilation for respiratory failure
* Fluid resuscitation and pressor support for hypotension
* Antibiotics for urinary tract infection and atypical pathogens
* Sedation and analgesia for pain and anxiety
* Monitoring for signs of bleeding and infection
* Active type and screen for blood transfusion
* Repeat hematocrit and guaiac stools to monitor for anemia and gastrointestinal bleeding.

The patient's code status is full code, and her disposition is ICU pending clinical improvement.

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old female with a history of COPD, moderate to severe aortic stenosis, and diastolic heart failure who presented to the emergency department with progressive dyspnea on exertion and cough productive of clear sputum. She was transferred to the ICU after experiencing a PEA arrest with evidence of unstable T11 fracture. The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation and has been diagnosed with respiratory failure, acute and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). She has also been diagnosed with bacteremia, sepsis, and urinary tract infection (UTI).

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 100.8°F, heart rate of 85 beats per minute, blood pressure of 79/47 mmHg, respiratory rate of 19 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 97%. She is receiving IV antibiotics, including cefepime, ciprofloxacin, and linezolid, as well as IV fluids and vasopressors to maintain blood pressure.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely to worsen due to her underlying COPD and the presence of bacteremia and sepsis.
2. Sepsis: The patient's bacteremia and UTI increase the risk of sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's aortic stenosis and diastolic heart failure increase the risk of cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias, heart failure, and cardiac arrest.
4. Neurological complications: The patient's history of PEA arrest and potential cord injury increase the risk of neurological complications, such as spinal cord injury, paralysis, and cognitive impairment.
5. Infection: The patient's bacteremia and UTI increase the risk of infection, which can lead to further complications and organ dysfunction.
6. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of lovenox administration and recent gastrointestinal bleeding increase the risk of further bleeding and gastrointestinal complications.
7. Kidney injury: The patient's sepsis and UTI increase the risk of kidney injury, which can lead to acute kidney injury and chronic kidney disease.
8. Liver injury: The patient's sepsis and UTI increase the risk of liver injury, which can lead to acute liver failure and chronic liver disease.
9. Pancreatitis: The patient's sepsis and UTI increase the risk of pancreatitis, which can lead to acute pancreatitis and chronic pancreatitis.

Recommendations:

1. Continue IV antibiotics, including cefepime, ciprofloxacin, and linezolid, to treat bacteremia and UTI.
2. Continue IV fluids and vasopressors to maintain blood pressure and perfusion.
3. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust mechanical ventilation as needed.
4. Monitor the patient's cardiac status closely and adjust treatment as needed to prevent cardiac complications.
5. Monitor the patient's neurological status closely and adjust treatment as needed to prevent neurological complications.
6. Monitor the patient's gastrointestinal status closely and adjust treatment as needed to prevent gastrointestinal bleeding and complications.
7. Monitor the patient's kidney and liver function closely and adjust treatment as needed to prevent kidney and liver injury.
8. Consider consulting a gastroenterologist or a nephrologist to manage the patient's gastrointestinal and kidney complications.
9. Consider consulting a cardiologist to manage the patient's cardiac complications.

   moderate to severe aortic stenosis and diastolic heart failure who
   presented to [**Location (un) 1415**] on [**2119-12-30**] with progressive dyspnea on exertion
   and cough productive of clear sputum transferred here after PEA arrest
   with evidence of unstable T11 fracture. Cord injury very likely, very
   poor surgical candidate, so will need to discuss this further with
   Ortho, Anesthetics and family. Otherwise treat respiratory
   failure/COPD.
   Shortness of breath/Hypercarbic respiratory failure
   Patient with known COPD at baseline on home oxygen.  Transition to PSV,
   will wean FiO2 for sat 90% and continue steroids / abx for component of
   COPD flare / infection. CXR have been unremarkable but CT chest with
   multiple small nodules (seeding?) which could be infectious in origin.
   - Continue CMV
   - Continue solumedrol 80 mg IV Q8H
   - Continue albuterol and ipratropium
   Autonomic Lability and Hypotension
   Interesting
 unknown etiology.  DM, CMV, pain (some not transmitted to
   forebrain/at spinal level/brainstem), spinal injury, sepsis, UTI, PNA,
   other contributors.
   - Treat underlying causes, infection, pain.
   - Fluid challenge now for resuscitation goals of CVP > 10, UOP > 30
   cc/hr, MAP > 60
   - Continue fentanyl and versed (instead of Propofol)
   - Check mixed venous oxygen saturation
   - Phenylephrine for pressor as needed
   PEA arrest
   Enzymes now trending down. Echo not remarkable.  Escaped serious
   myocardial damage. Typical CAD management.
   Unstable T11 fracture
   Family and Ortho/Anesthetics agreed yesterday to leave this for now,
   pending improved stability for surgery.
   Leukocytosis
   Contribution by PEA arrest, UTI, steroids, spinal fracture, but still
   need to be sensitive to history of MRSA bacteremia, now positive blood
   culture, possible PNA and MRSA. Will hold off on Vancomycin for now
   given previous adverse reaction (consider linezolid if febrile or
   others signs of sepsis).
   - On linezolid (vancomycin allergy convincing), cefepime, ciprofloxacin

   lovenox administration.
   - Maintain active type and screen

   - Guaiac stools
   - Transfusion goal > 25 in periarrest period
   Right Ear Bleeding
   Possible injury to tympanic membrane during resuscitation in context of

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 76-year-old female with a history of COPD, moderate to severe aortic stenosis, and diastolic heart failure. She presented to the emergency department with progressive dyspnea on exertion and cough productive of clear sputum, and was transferred to the ICU after a PEA arrest with evidence of an unstable T11 fracture.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a FiO2 of 30% and a PEEP of 10 cmH2O. She has a respiratory acidosis with a pH of 7.31 and a PaCO2 of 65 mmHg.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has a hypotensive episode with a blood pressure of 79/47 mmHg, and is receiving vasopressors. Her cardiac enzymes are trending down, and an echocardiogram showed no remarkable findings.
* Neurological: The patient is sedated and has a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 3. She has a history of autonomic lability and hypotension, which may be contributing to her current condition.
* Renal: The patient has a urinary tract infection (UTI) and is receiving treatment with ceftriaxone.
* Gastrointestinal: The patient has a history of mild gastrointestinal bleeding and is receiving anticoagulation therapy.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory acidosis and hypoxemia may worsen if her ventilation settings are not adjusted accordingly.
2. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's hypotension and vasopressor dependence may indicate a high risk of cardiovascular instability and arrhythmias.
3. Neurological deterioration: The patient's sedation and autonomic lability may lead to further neurological deterioration, including seizures or brain death.
4. Renal insufficiency: The patient's UTI and receipt of nephrotoxic medications may exacerbate her pre-existing kidney disease.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of mild gastrointestinal bleeding and anticoagulation therapy may increase her risk of further bleeding episodes.
6. Infection: The patient's positive blood culture and UTI may indicate a high risk of sepsis and infection-related complications.
7. Pneumonia: The patient's respiratory failure and positive respiratory culture may indicate a high risk of pneumonia.
8. Sepsis: The patient's positive blood culture and UTI may indicate a high risk of sepsis and multi-organ failure.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential complications, it is recommended that she continue to receive close monitoring and treatment in the ICU, with adjustments to her ventilation settings, vasopressors, and medications as needed.

Summary:

The patient is a 69-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU after experiencing a PEA arrest at a location, likely due to a COPD flare. He was successfully resuscitated and has been receiving treatment in the ICU for the past 24 hours. The patient has a history of allergies to penicillins, sulfonamides, and vancomycin. He has been receiving antibiotics, including Cefepime, Cipro, and Linezolid, for suspected bacteremia.

The patient's current condition is characterized by:

* Hypotension (not in shock)
* Respiratory failure (not ARDS)
* Trauma, status post (S/P)
* ICU care, including mechanical ventilation and vasopressor support
* Nutritional support with a pulmonary diet
* Glycemic control with insulin therapy
* Prophylactic measures for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Elevated white blood cell count (WBC) and neutrophil count
* Elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine levels
* Elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and troponin-T levels
* Elevated inflammatory markers, including C-reactive protein (CRP) and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)
* Negative urine legionella antigen

The patient's imaging studies show:

* CXR pending/pending read
* Echo study showing mild aortic stenosis, moderate pulmonary artery hypertension, and mild mitral regurgitation

Potential medical complications that may arise:

* Sepsis and septic shock due to bacteremia
* Respiratory failure and ARDS due to pneumonia or other lung injury
* Cardiac arrhythmias and cardiac arrest due to electrolyte imbalances or other cardiac conditions
* Renal failure due to acute kidney injury or pre-existing kidney disease
* Infection and sepsis due to catheters or other invasive devices
* Pressure ulcers and skin breakdown due to prolonged immobility and poor nutrition
* Gastrointestinal bleeding and perforation due to stress ulcer or other gastrointestinal conditions

The patient's code status is full code, and his disposition is still uncertain at this time. Further evaluation and management are needed to address his ongoing medical needs and prevent potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 76 year old female with a history of COPD on home oxygen,
   mild aortic stenosis and diastolic heart failure who presented to
   [**Location (un) 1415**] on [**2119-12-30**] with progressive dyspnea on exertion and cough
   productive of clear sputum transferred here after PEA arrest with
   evidence of unstable T11 fracture. Cord injury very likely, very poor
   surgical candidate. After discussing with family, will hold on any
   surgical intervention for spine.
   Shortness of breath/Hypercarbic respiratory failure
   Patient with known COPD at baseline on home oxygen.  Transition to PSV,
   will wean FiO2 for sat 90% and continue steroids / abx for component of
   COPD flare / infection. CXR have been unremarkable but CT chest with
   multiple small nodules (seeding?) which could be infectious in origin.
   - Continue CMV
 transition to CPAP today
   - Continue solumedrol 80 mg IV Q8H
   - Continue albuterol and ipratropium
   - Continue cefepime, linezolid (vancomycin results in desquamative
   reaction)
   Autonomic Lability and Hypotension
   Interesting
 unknown etiology.  DM, CMV, pain (some not transmitted to
   forebrain/at spinal level/brainstem), spinal injury, sepsis, UTI, PNA,
   other contributors.
   - Treat underlying causes, infection, pain.
   - Fluid challenge now for resuscitation goals of CVP > 10, UOP > 30
   cc/hr, MAP > 60
   - Continue fentanyl and versed (instead of Propofol)
   - Check mixed venous oxygen saturation
   - Phenylephrine for pressor in low dose, with supplementary fluid
   give 2L today with goal of being positive by 0.5-1L.
   PEA arrest
   Enzymes now trending down. Echo not remarkable.  Escaped serious
   myocardial damage. Typical CAD management.
   Unstable T11 fracture
   Family and Ortho/Anesthetics agreed yesterday to leave this for now,
   pending improved stability for surgery.
   Shoulder Pain
   Dislocation on shoulder x-ray and exam.  Pain controlled now (just on
   movement)
 will use fentanyl boluses if needed during relocation or
   recs of Ortho.
   - Ortho following and will replace
   Leukocytosis and Sepsis
   Contribution by PEA arrest, UTI, steroids, spinal fracture, but still
   need to be sensitive to history of MRSA bacteremia, now positive blood
   culture (coag negative staph.), possible PNA and MRSA. On linezolid now
   (given vancomycin reaction
 desquamative), will probably not convert
   to daptomycin because coag negative.  Will continue linezolid and
   cefepime for now.
   - On linezolid (vancomycin allergy convincing), cefepime
   Urinary Tract Infection
   Ciprofloxacin stopped based on coverage above.
   Diabetes Mellitus
   Stable
 controlled on ISS.
   Inactive issues:
   Anemia
   Stable. Hematocrit 28 on arrival from 36 on [**2119-12-30**]. Now stable at 29.
   Likely dilutional in the setting of fluid resuscitation post-arrest.
   Also a report of mild gastrointesinal bleeding in the setting of
   lovenox administration.
   - Maintain active type and screen
   - Trend hematocrit
   - Guaiac stools
   - Transfusion goal > 25 in periarrest period
   Right Ear Bleeding
   Possible injury to tympanic membrane during resuscitation in context of
   anticoagulation.  Normal head CT at [**Location (un) 1415**].
   - Otoscopy
   ICU care:
   Sedation: Versed and fentanyl with propofol.
   FEN: Normal saline boluses for resuscitation parameters as above,
   replete electrolytes, has NGT for tube feeds.
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, PPI

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old female with a history of COPD, mild aortic stenosis, and diastolic heart failure who presented to the emergency department with progressive dyspnea on exertion and cough productive of clear sputum. She was transferred to the ICU after experiencing a PEA arrest with evidence of an unstable T11 fracture. The patient has a poor surgical candidate status due to her unstable condition and risk of cord injury.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: Shortness of breath/Hypercarbic respiratory failure, transitioning to CPAP, and continuing steroids and antibiotics for component of COPD flare/infection.
* Cardiovascular: Autonomic lability and hypotension, likely due to unknown etiology, and treated with fluids, pressors, and vasopressors.
* Infectious: Positive blood culture for coag-negative staph, and possible PNA and MRSA.
* Orthopedic: Unstable T11 fracture, and family and orthopedic/anesthetic team agreed to hold surgery for now.
* Neurological: PEA arrest, and enzymes trending down, with no remarkable findings on echo.
* Gastrointestinal: Mild gastrointestinal bleeding in the setting of lovenox administration.
* Hematological: Anemia, stable, and likely dilutional in the setting of fluid resuscitation post-arrest.
* Other: Right ear bleeding, possible injury to tympanic membrane during resuscitation in context of anticoagulation.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory: Pneumonia, respiratory failure, and hypercarbic respiratory failure.
2. Cardiovascular: Cardiac arrest, cardiogenic shock, and cardiac tamponade.
3. Infectious: Sepsis, bacteremia, and MRSA infection.
4. Orthopedic: Spinal cord injury, spinal instability, and fracture non-union.
5. Neurological: Cerebral edema, brainstem compression, and spinal cord compression.
6. Gastrointestinal: Gastrointestinal bleeding, gastrointestinal perforation, and gastrointestinal obstruction.
7. Hematological: Anemia, bleeding diathesis, and disseminated intravascular coagulation.
8. Other: Right ear bleeding, tympanic membrane perforation, and otitis media.

Recommendations:

1. Continue CPAP and wean FiO2 to 90%.
2. Continue steroids and antibiotics for component of COPD flare/infection.
3. Monitor for signs of sepsis and bacteremia, and consider adding daptomycin if coag-negative staph is identified.
4. Continue fluids, pressors, and vasopressors to manage autonomic lability and hypotension.
5. Monitor for signs of spinal cord injury and spinal instability, and consider surgical intervention if necessary.
6. Monitor for signs of cerebral edema and brainstem compression, and consider surgical intervention if necessary.
7. Monitor for signs of gastrointestinal bleeding and perforation, and consider endoscopy if necessary.
8. Monitor for signs of anemia and bleeding diathesis, and consider transfusion if necessary.
9. Monitor for signs of right ear bleeding and tympanic membrane perforation, and consider otolaryngology consultation if necessary.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 76 year old female with a history of COPD on home oxygen (2L
   baseline), mild aortic stenosis and diastolic heart failure who
   presented to [**Location (un) 1415**] on [**2119-12-30**] with progressive dyspnea on exertion
   and cough productive of clear sputum transferred here after PEA arrest
   with evidence of unstable T11 fracture. Cord injury very likely, very
   poor surgical candidate. After discussing with family, will hold on any
   surgical intervention for spine. Now sputum with coag + staph and
   (likely contaminant) coag
 in blood culture.
   Agree with plan to manage hypercarbic respiratory failure / COPD flare
   / nosocomial pneumonia with VAC, steroids, and broad antibiotic coverge
   for GNRs. For GPC bacteremia, on linezolid, old lines have been
   changed, echo s vegitation - will ask ID re linezolid vs dapto in this
   setting. Will continue neo for BP support, bolus for CVP >12 as she is
   likely very preload dependent, check CvO2. Neuro status stable post
   arrest. Will ask ortho to relocate shoulder. For spine fx, unable to
   offer surgery given ongoing infection at the moment, will continue d/w
   family. Start TFs, communication with daughter, needs SW consult for
   support. Remainder of plan as outlined above.
   Shortness of breath/Hypercarbic respiratory failure
   Patient with known COPD at baseline on home oxygen. Trial of MMV
   yesterday resulted in no spontaneous breathing. Thererfore will check
   gas and if acceptable continue present pressure support for now,
   despite short apneic periods.  Will reduce FiO2 to 30%. Continue but
   reduce steroids for COPD, continue linezolid and cefepime given sputum
   culture. Also continue nebs. CXR stable to improved.
   - Continue CMV
 reduce FiO2 to 30%, check ABG, continue pressure
   support if ABG acceptable
   - Solumedrol to 40 mg IV Q8H
   - Continue albuterol and ipratropium
   - Continue cefepime, linezolid (vancomycin results in desquamative
   reaction) (for 8d course of both since start on [**1-2**])
   Autonomic Lability and Hypotension
   Improved. Interesting
 unknown etiology.  DM, CMV, pain (some not
   transmitted to forebrain/at spinal level/brainstem), spinal injury,
   sepsis, UTI, PNA, other contributors.
   - Treat underlying causes, infection, pain
   - Fluid challenge now for resuscitation goals of CVP > 10, UOP > 30
   cc/hr, MAP > 60
   - Continue fentanyl and versed (instead of Propofol)
   - Check mixed venous oxygen saturation
   - Fluids to support pressure and attempt to wean from pressors
   Pain
   Denies when asked, but possible, so will cover.
   - Tylenol standing to synergize opioids (fentanyl for now)
   - Reevaluate if need to reduce sedation with fentanyl
   Sedation
   We feel that present level of sedation is acceptable. Conscious
   somnolent, but likely light enough for breathing and deep enough for
   pain control (shoulder and back).
   PEA arrest
   Enzymes now trending down. Echo not remarkable.  Escaped serious
   myocardial damage. Typical CAD management.
   Unstable T11 fracture
   Family and Ortho/Anesthetics agreed yesterday to leave this for now,
   pending improved stability for surgery. Will discuss with anesthetics
   and ortho about whether would like to operate before extubation.
   Shoulder Dislocation
   Reduced by Ortho.
   - Continue use of sling and monitor for dislocation and signs of pain
   Leukocytosis and Sepsis
   Trending down now from 18-19 now 10. Contribution by PEA arrest, UTI,
   steroids, spinal fracture, but still need to be sensitive to history of
   MRSA bacteremia, positive sputum and possible (though unlikely) sepsis.
   On linezolid now (given vancomycin reaction
 desquamative), will
   probably not convert to daptomycin because coag negative.  Will
   continue linezolid and cefepime until eight-day course complete on
   [**2120-1-7**].
   Urinary Tract Infection

   Stable
 controlled on ISS (even with steroids).

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old female with a history of COPD, mild aortic stenosis, and diastolic heart failure who presented with progressive dyspnea on exertion and cough productive of clear sputum. She had a PEA arrest with evidence of unstable T11 fracture and was transferred to the ICU. She has been diagnosed with hypercarbic respiratory failure, COPD flare, nosocomial pneumonia, and urinary tract infection. She has been treated with antibiotics, steroids, and pain management.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pneumonia: The patient's sputum culture grew Pseudomonas aeruginosa, which is a common cause of nosocomial pneumonia. She may require further antibiotics and respiratory support.
2. Sepsis: The patient's blood culture grew coagulase-negative Staphylococcus, which may indicate sepsis. She may require further antibiotics and supportive care.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and she may require further respiratory support, such as non-invasive positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV) or mechanical ventilation.
4. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac status is uncertain, and she may require further cardiac monitoring and support.
5. Neurological complications: The patient's neurological status is stable, but she may require further monitoring and support.
6. Wound complications: The patient's T11 fracture may require surgical intervention, and she may be at risk for wound complications, such as infection or dehiscence.
7. Bloodstream infection: The patient's blood culture grew coagulase-negative Staphylococcus, which may indicate a bloodstream infection. She may require further antibiotics and supportive care.
8. Sternal instability: The patient's T11 fracture may cause sternal instability, which may require further evaluation and management.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antibiotics and respiratory support as ordered.
2. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust therapy as needed.
3. Monitor the patient's cardiac status closely and adjust therapy as needed.
4. Monitor the patient's neurological status closely and adjust therapy as needed.
5. Consider surgical intervention for the T11 fracture if the patient's condition stabilizes.
6. Monitor the patient's wound for signs of infection or dehiscence.
7. Consider further evaluation and management of the patient's bloodstream infection.
8. Consider further evaluation and management of the patient's sternal instability.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 76 year old female with a history of COPD on home oxygen (2L
   baseline), mild aortic stenosis and diastolic heart failure who
   presented to [**Location (un) 1415**] on [**2119-12-30**] with progressive dyspnea on exertion
   and cough productive of clear sputum transferred here after PEA arrest
   with evidence of unstable T11 fracture. Cord injury very likely, very
   poor surgical candidate. After discussing with family, will hold on any
   surgical intervention for spine. Now sputum with coag + staph and
   (likely contaminant) coag
 in blood culture.
   Agree with plan to manage hypercarbic respiratory failure / COPD flare
   / nosocomial pneumonia with VAC, steroids, and broad antibiotic coverge
   for GNRs. For GPC bacteremia, on linezolid, old lines have been
   changed, echo s vegitation - will ask ID re linezolid vs dapto in this
   setting. Will continue neo for BP support, bolus for CVP >12 as she is
   likely very preload dependent, check CvO2. Neuro status stable post
   arrest. Will ask ortho to relocate shoulder. For spine fx, unable to
   offer surgery given ongoing infection at the moment, will continue d/w
   family. Start TFs, communication with daughter, needs SW consult for
   support. Remainder of plan as outlined above.
   Shortness of breath/Hypercarbic respiratory failure
   Patient with known COPD at baseline on home oxygen. Trial of MMV
   yesterday resulted in no spontaneous breathing. Thererfore will check
   gas and if acceptable continue present pressure support for now,
   despite short apneic periods.  Will reduce FiO2 to 30%. Continue but
   reduce steroids for COPD, continue linezolid and cefepime given sputum
   culture. Also continue nebs. CXR stable to improved.
   - Continue CMV
 reduce FiO2 to 30%, check ABG, continue pressure
   support if ABG acceptable
   - Solumedrol to 40 mg IV Q8H
   - Continue albuterol and ipratropium
   - Continue cefepime, linezolid (vancomycin results in desquamative
   reaction) (for 8d course of both since start on [**1-2**])
   Autonomic Lability and Hypotension
   Improved. Interesting
 unknown etiology.  DM, CMV, pain (some not
   transmitted to forebrain/at spinal level/brainstem), spinal injury,
   sepsis, UTI, PNA, other contributors.
   - Treat underlying causes, infection, pain
   - Fluid challenge now for resuscitation goals of CVP > 10, UOP > 30
   cc/hr, MAP > 60
   - Continue fentanyl and versed (instead of Propofol)
   - Check mixed venous oxygen saturation
   - Fluids to support pressure and attempt to wean from pressors
   Pain
   Denies when asked, but possible, so will cover.
   - Tylenol standing to synergize opioids (fentanyl for now)
   - Reevaluate if need to reduce sedation with fentanyl
   Sedation
   We feel that present level of sedation is acceptable. Conscious
   somnolent, but likely light enough for breathing and deep enough for
   pain control (shoulder and back).
   PEA arrest
   Enzymes now trending down. Echo not remarkable.  Escaped serious
   myocardial damage. Typical CAD management.
   Unstable T11 fracture
   Family and Ortho/Anesthetics agreed yesterday to leave this for now,
   pending improved stability for surgery. Will discuss with anesthetics
   and ortho about whether would like to operate before extubation.
   Shoulder Dislocation
   Reduced by Ortho.
   - Continue use of sling and monitor for dislocation and signs of pain
   Leukocytosis and Sepsis
   Trending down now from 18-19 now 10. Contribution by PEA arrest, UTI,
   steroids, spinal fracture, but still need to be sensitive to history of
   MRSA bacteremia, positive sputum and possible (though unlikely) sepsis.
   On linezolid now (given vancomycin reaction
 desquamative), will
   probably not convert to daptomycin because coag negative.  Will
   continue linezolid and cefepime until eight-day course complete on
   [**2120-1-7**].
   Urinary Tract Infection
   Ciprofloxacin stopped based on coverage above.
   Diabetes Mellitus
   Stable
 controlled on ISS (even with steroids).
   Anemia
   Stable to lower. Hematocrit 28 on arrival from 36 on [**2119-12-30**]. Now
   24.5. Likely dilutional.
   - Maintain active type and screen
   - Trend hematocrit
   - Guaiac stools
   - Transfusion goal > 25 in periarrest period (repeat before
   transfusing)
   ICU care
   Sedation: Versed and fentanyl
   FEN: Normal saline boluses for resuscitation parameters as above,
   replete electrolytes, has NGT for tube feeds.
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, PPI
   Access: Right IJ placed, left radial arterial line

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 76-year-old female with a history of COPD, mild aortic stenosis, and diastolic heart failure who presented with progressive dyspnea on exertion and cough productive of clear sputum. She was transferred to the ICU after a PEA arrest and was found to have an unstable T11 fracture.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: She is intubated and on ventilator support with a CMV mode, FiO2 of 40%, and PEEP of 10 cmH2O. Her ABG results show a pH of 7.37, pCO2 of 56 mmHg, and pO2 of 125 mmHg.
* Cardiovascular: She has a history of PEA arrest and is currently on pressors to support her blood pressure. Her cardiac enzymes are trending down, and an echo was not remarkable.
* Neurological: She is conscious and somnolent, but able to respond to verbal stimuli and has some appropriate simple responses.
* Infectious: She has a positive sputum culture for Pseudomonas aeruginosa and coag + staph, and a blood culture for GPC bacteremia.
* Renal: Her urine output is stable, and her creatinine is 0.7 mg/dL.
* Hematological: She has leukocytosis, trending down from 18-19 to 10, and anemia, with a hematocrit of 24.5.
* Other: She has a history of diabetes mellitus, controlled on ISS, and is on prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP.

The patient's medical complications include:

* Hypercarbic respiratory failure
* Unstable T11 fracture
* PEA arrest
* Sepsis
* UTI
* Anemia
* Leukocytosis

The potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure
* Cardiac arrhythmias
* Sepsis-related organ dysfunction
* Pneumonia
* Urinary tract infection
* Anemia-related complications
* Leukocytosis-related complications

The plan of care includes:

* Continue CMV mode and reduce FiO2 to 30%
* Continue pressure support if ABG is acceptable
* Solumedrol to 40 mg IV Q8H
* Continue albuterol and ipratropium
* Continue cefepime and linezolid for 8-day course
* Treat underlying causes of autonomic lability and hypotension
* Continue fentanyl and versed for sedation
* Check mixed venous oxygen saturation
* Fluid challenge for resuscitation goals
* Continue to monitor and manage the patient's condition closely.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 76 year old female with a history of COPD on home oxygen,
   mild aortic stenosis and diastolic heart failure who presented to
   [**Location (un) 1415**] on [**2119-12-30**] with progressive dyspnea on exertion and cough
   productive of clear sputum transferred here after PEA arrest with
   evidence of unstable T11 fracture. Cord injury very likely, very poor
   surgical candidate. After discussing with family, will hold on any
   surgical intervention for spine.
   Agree with plan to manage hypercarbic respiratory failure / COPD flare
   / nosocomial pneumonia with VAC, steroids, and broad antibiotic coverge
   for GNRs. For GPC bacteremia, on linezolid, old lines have been
   changed, echo s vegitation - will ask ID re linezolid vs dapto in this
   setting. Will continue neo for BP support, bolus for CVP >12 as she is
   likely very preload dependent, check CvO2. Neuro status stable post
   arrest. Will ask ortho to relocate shoulder. For spine fx, unable to
   offer surgery given ongoing infection at the moment, will continue d/w
   family. Start TFs, communication with daughter, needs SW consult for
   support. Remainder of plan as outlined above.
   Shortness of breath/Hypercarbic respiratory failure
   Patient with known COPD at baseline on home oxygen.  Transition to PSV,
   will wean FiO2 for sat 90% and continue steroids / abx for component of
   COPD flare / infection. CXR have been unremarkable but CT chest with
   multiple small nodules (seeding?) which could be infectious in origin.
   - Continue CMV
 transition to CPAP today
   - Continue solumedrol 80 mg IV Q8H
   - Continue albuterol and ipratropium
   - Continue cefepime, linezolid (vancomycin results in desquamative
   reaction)
   Autonomic Lability and Hypotension
   Interesting
 unknown etiology.  DM, CMV, pain (some not transmitted to
   forebrain/at spinal level/brainstem), spinal injury, sepsis, UTI, PNA,
   other contributors.
   - Treat underlying causes, infection, pain.
   - Fluid challenge now for resuscitation goals of CVP > 10, UOP > 30
   cc/hr, MAP > 60
   - Continue fentanyl and versed (instead of Propofol)
   - Check mixed venous oxygen saturation
   - Phenylephrine for pressor in low dose, with supplementary fluid
   give 2L today with goal of being positive by 0.5-1L.
   PEA arrest
   Enzymes now trending down. Echo not remarkable.  Escaped serious
   myocardial damage. Typical CAD management.
   Unstable T11 fracture
   Family and Ortho/Anesthetics agreed yesterday to leave this for now,
   pending improved stability for surgery.
   Shoulder Pain
   Dislocation on shoulder x-ray and exam.  Pain controlled now (just on
   movement)
 will use fentanyl boluses if needed during relocation or
   recs of Ortho.
   - Ortho following and will replace
   Leukocytosis and Sepsis
   Contribution by PEA arrest, UTI, steroids, spinal fracture, but still
   need to be sensitive to history of MRSA bacteremia, now positive blood
   culture (coag negative staph.), possible PNA and MRSA. On linezolid now
   (given vancomycin reaction
 desquamative), will probably not convert
   to daptomycin because coag negative.  Will continue linezolid and
   cefepime for now.
   - On linezolid (vancomycin allergy convincing), cefepime

   Stable
 controlled on ISS.

   Stable. Hematocrit 28 on arrival from 36 on [**2119-12-30**]. Now stable at 29.

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old female with a history of COPD, mild aortic stenosis, and diastolic heart failure who presented to the hospital with progressive dyspnea on exertion and cough productive of clear sputum. She had a PEA arrest and was found to have an unstable T11 fracture. She was intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation. She has been receiving antibiotics, steroids, and other medications to manage her hypercarbic respiratory failure, COPD flare, and nosocomial pneumonia. She also has a blood culture positive for coag-negative staph, which is being treated with linezolid.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient has a blood culture positive for coag-negative staph, which can lead to sepsis.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient has hypercarbic respiratory failure, which can worsen if not managed properly.
3. Pneumonia: The patient has a nosocomial pneumonia, which can lead to further respiratory failure and sepsis.
4. Shock: The patient had a PEA arrest, which can lead to shock if not managed properly.
5. Cardiovascular complications: The patient has mild aortic stenosis, which can lead to cardiovascular complications such as heart failure or arrhythmias.
6. Spinal cord injury: The patient has an unstable T11 fracture, which can lead to spinal cord injury if not managed properly.
7. Urinary tract infection: The patient has a urinary tract infection, which can lead to further complications if not managed properly.
8. Diabetes mellitus: The patient has diabetes mellitus, which can lead to further complications if not managed properly.
9. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient has a report of mild gastrointestinal bleeding, which can lead to further complications if not managed properly.
10. Autonomic lability: The patient has autonomic lability, which can lead to further complications if not managed properly.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antibiotics and antifungals as prescribed.
2. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust ventilation settings as necessary.
3. Monitor the patient's cardiovascular status closely and adjust medications as necessary.
4. Monitor the patient's spinal cord injury status closely and adjust treatment as necessary.
5. Monitor the patient's urinary tract infection status closely and adjust treatment as necessary.
6. Monitor the patient's diabetes mellitus status closely and adjust treatment as necessary.
7. Monitor the patient's gastrointestinal bleeding status closely and adjust treatment as necessary.
8. Monitor the patient's autonomic lability status closely and adjust treatment as necessary.
9. Consider consulting with a specialist, such as a pulmonologist or cardiologist, for further management of the patient's condition.
10. Consider transferring the patient to a higher level of care, such as an intensive care unit, if necessary.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 76 year old female with a history of COPD on home oxygen (2L
   baseline), mild aortic stenosis and diastolic heart failure who
   presented to [**Location (un) 1415**] on [**2119-12-30**] with progressive dyspnea on exertion
   and cough productive of clear sputum transferred here after PEA arrest
   with evidence of unstable T11 fracture. Cord injury very likely, very
   poor surgical candidate. After discussing with family, will hold on any
   surgical intervention for spine. Now sputum with coag + staph and
   (likely contaminant) coag
 in blood culture.
   Shortness of breath/Hypercarbic respiratory failure
   Patient with known COPD at baseline on home oxygen. Trial of MMV on
   [**1-3**] resulted in no spontaneous breathing. Thererfore will check gas
   and if acceptable continue present pressure support for now, despite
   short apneic periods.  Will reduce FiO2 to 30%. Continue but reduce
   steroids for COPD, continue linezolid and cefepime given sputum
   culture. Also continue nebs. CXR stable to improved.
   - Continue CMV
 reduce FiO2 to 30%, check ABG, continue pressure
   support if ABG acceptable
   - Solumedrol to 40 mg IV Q8H
   - Continue albuterol and ipratropium
   - Continue cefepime, linezolid (vancomycin results in desquamative
   reaction) (for 8d course of both since start on [**1-2**])
   Autonomic Lability and Hypotension
   Improved. Interesting
 unknown etiology.  DM, CMV, pain (some not
   transmitted to forebrain/at spinal level/brainstem), spinal injury,
   sepsis, UTI, PNA, other contributors.
   - Treat underlying causes, infection, pain
   - Fluid challenge now for resuscitation goals of CVP > 10, UOP > 30
   cc/hr, MAP > 60
   - Continue fentanyl and versed (instead of Propofol)
   - Check mixed venous oxygen saturation
   - Fluids to support pressure and attempt to wean from pressors
   Pain
   Denies when asked, but possible, so will cover.
   - Tylenol standing to synergize opioids (fentanyl for now)
   - Reevaluate if need to reduce sedation with fentanyl
   Sedation
   We feel that present level of sedation is acceptable. Conscious
   somnolent, but likely light enough for breathing and deep enough for
   pain control (shoulder and back).
   PEA arrest
   Enzymes now trending down. Echo not remarkable.  Escaped serious
   myocardial damage. Typical CAD management.
   Unstable T11 fracture
   Family and Ortho/Anesthetics agreed yesterday to leave this for now,
   pending improved stability for surgery. Will discuss with anesthetics
   and ortho about whether would like to operate before extubation.
   Shoulder Dislocation
   Reduced by Ortho.
   - Continue use of sling and monitor for dislocation and signs of pain
   Leukocytosis and Sepsis
   Trending down now from 18-19 now 10. Contribution by PEA arrest, UTI,
   steroids, spinal fracture, but still need to be sensitive to history of
   MRSA bacteremia, positive sputum and possible (though unlikely) sepsis.
   On linezolid now (given vancomycin reaction
 desquamative), will
   probably not convert to daptomycin because coag negative.  Will
   continue linezolid and cefepime until eight-day course complete on
   [**2120-1-7**].
   Urinary Tract Infection
   Ciprofloxacin stopped based on coverage above.
   Diabetes Mellitus
   Stable
 controlled on ISS (even with steroids).
   Anemia
   Stable to lower. Hematocrit 28 on arrival from 36 on [**2119-12-30**]. Now
   24.5. Likely dilutional.
   - Maintain active type and screen
   - Trend hematocrit
   - Guaiac stools
   - Transfusion goal > 25 in periarrest period (repeat before
   transfusing)
   ICU care
   Sedation: Versed and fentanyl
   FEN: Normal saline boluses for resuscitation parameters as above,
   replete electrolytes, has NGT for tube feeds.
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, PPI

Summary:

The patient is a 76-year-old female with a history of COPD, mild aortic stenosis, and diastolic heart failure who presented with progressive dyspnea on exertion and cough productive of clear sputum. She suffered a PEA arrest and was found to have an unstable T11 fracture. She is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation with a pressure support mode. She has a history of MRSA bacteremia, positive sputum, and possible sepsis. She is also experiencing autonomic lability and hypotension, and has a risk of developing a urinary tract infection.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's COPD and mechanical ventilation may lead to respiratory failure, which could be exacerbated by her unstable T11 fracture.
2. Sepsis: The patient's positive sputum and history of MRSA bacteremia put her at risk of developing sepsis, which could be further complicated by her autonomic lability and hypotension.
3. Autonomic Lability and Hypotension: The patient's autonomic lability and hypotension may lead to further complications, such as arrhythmias, cardiac arrest, or organ failure.
4. Urinary Tract Infection: The patient's history of UTI and the use of ciprofloxacin may increase her risk of developing a urinary tract infection.
5. Shoulder Dislocation: The patient's shoulder dislocation may lead to further complications, such as pain, limited mobility, and increased risk of infection.
6. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if she experiences further blood loss or has difficulty recovering from her PEA arrest.
7. Diabetes Mellitus: The patient's diabetes mellitus may require further management, especially if she experiences hyperglycemia or hypoglycemia.
8. Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis may indicate the presence of an underlying infection or inflammation, which could lead to further complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue mechanical ventilation with pressure support mode to manage the patient's respiratory failure.
2. Monitor the patient's sputum and blood cultures for signs of sepsis and adjust antibiotic therapy accordingly.
3. Manage the patient's autonomic lability and hypotension with fluids, vasopressors, and sedation as needed.
4. Continue prophylactic antibiotics to prevent UTI and monitor the patient's urine output and urinalysis.
5. Manage the patient's shoulder dislocation with a sling and monitor for signs of infection or limited mobility.
6. Monitor the patient's anemia and transfuse as needed to maintain a hemoglobin level of at least 10 g/dL.
7. Manage the patient's diabetes mellitus with insulin and monitor for signs of hyperglycemia or hypoglycemia.
8. Monitor the patient's leukocytosis and adjust antibiotic therapy accordingly.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 76 year old female with a history of COPD on home oxygen (2L
   baseline), mild aortic stenosis and diastolic heart failure who
   presented to [**Location (un) 1415**] on [**2119-12-30**] with progressive dyspnea on exertion
   and cough productive of clear sputum transferred here after PEA arrest
   with evidence of unstable T11 fracture. Cord injury very likely, very
   poor surgical candidate. After discussing with family, will hold on any
   surgical intervention for spine. Now sputum with coag + staph and
   (likely contaminant) coag
 in blood culture.
   Shortness of breath/Hypercarbic respiratory failure
   Patient with known COPD at baseline on home oxygen. Trial of MMV
   yesterday resulted in no spontaneous breathing. Thererfore will check
   gas and if acceptable continue present pressure support for now,
   despite short apneic periods.  Will reduce FiO2 to 30%. Continue but
   reduce steroids for COPD, continue linezolid and cefepime given sputum
   culture. Also continue nebs. CXR stable to improved.
   - Continue CMV
 reduce FiO2 to 30%, check ABG, continue pressure
   support if ABG acceptable
   - Solumedrol to 40 mg IV Q8H
   - Continue albuterol and ipratropium
   - Continue cefepime, linezolid (vancomycin results in desquamative
   reaction) (for 8d course of both since start on [**1-2**])
   Autonomic Lability and Hypotension
   Improved. Interesting
 unknown etiology.  DM, CMV, pain (some not
   transmitted to forebrain/at spinal level/brainstem), spinal injury,
   sepsis, UTI, PNA, other contributors.
   - Treat underlying causes, infection, pain
   - Fluid challenge now for resuscitation goals of CVP > 10, UOP > 30
   cc/hr, MAP > 60
   - Continue fentanyl and versed (instead of Propofol)
   - Check mixed venous oxygen saturation
   - Fluids to support pressure and attempt to wean from pressors
   Pain
   Denies when asked, but possible, so will cover.
   - Tylenol standing to synergize opioids (fentanyl for now)
   - Reevaluate if need to reduce sedation with fentanyl
   Sedation
   We feel that present level of sedation is acceptable. Conscious
   somnolent, but likely light enough for breathing and deep enough for
   pain control (shoulder and back).
   PEA arrest
   Enzymes now trending down. Echo not remarkable.  Escaped serious
   myocardial damage. Typical CAD management.
   Unstable T11 fracture
   Family and Ortho/Anesthetics agreed yesterday to leave this for now,
   pending improved stability for surgery. Will discuss with anesthetics
   and ortho about whether would like to operate before extubation.
   Shoulder Dislocation
   Reduced by Ortho.
   - Continue use of sling and monitor for dislocation and signs of pain
   Leukocytosis and Sepsis
   Trending down now from 18-19 now 10. Contribution by PEA arrest, UTI,
   steroids, spinal fracture, but still need to be sensitive to history of
   MRSA bacteremia, positive sputum and possible (though unlikely) sepsis.
   On linezolid now (given vancomycin reaction
 desquamative), will
   probably not convert to daptomycin because coag negative.  Will
   continue linezolid and cefepime until eight-day course complete on
   [**2120-1-7**].
   Urinary Tract Infection
   Ciprofloxacin stopped based on coverage above.
   Diabetes Mellitus
   Stable
 controlled on ISS (even with steroids).
   Anemia
   Stable to lower. Hematocrit 28 on arrival from 36 on [**2119-12-30**]. Now
   24.5. Likely dilutional.
   - Maintain active type and screen
   - Trend hematocrit
   - Guaiac stools
   - Transfusion goal > 25 in periarrest period (repeat before
   transfusing)
   ICU care
   Sedation: Versed and fentanyl
   FEN: Normal saline boluses for resuscitation parameters as above,
   replete electrolytes, has NGT for tube feeds.
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin, PPI

Based on the patient's progress note, I summarize the following:

The patient is a 76-year-old female with a history of COPD, mild aortic stenosis, and diastolic heart failure who presented to the hospital with progressive dyspnea on exertion and cough productive of clear sputum. She suffered a PEA arrest and has an unstable T11 fracture. The patient is currently in the ICU and is receiving mechanical ventilation, oxygen therapy, and medication for pain, sedation, and antibiotics.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.3°C, heart rate of 100 bpm, and blood pressure of 113/56 mmHg. Her oxygen saturation is 97% on 30% FiO2, and her respiratory rate is 17 inspirations per minute.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 18.5 K/uL, hemoglobin of 8.0 g/dL, and platelet count of 279 K/uL. Her electrolyte levels are within normal limits, and her blood urea nitrogen and creatinine levels are slightly elevated. Her liver function tests show mild elevations in alanine aminotransferase and aspartate aminotransferase.

The patient has a history of MRSA bacteremia and is currently receiving antibiotics for pneumonia. She has also been diagnosed with sepsis and is receiving fluids and vasopressors to support her blood pressure.

The patient's medical complications include:

1. Pneumonia: The patient has a history of COPD and has been diagnosed with pneumonia, which is likely related to her COPD.
2. Sepsis: The patient has been diagnosed with sepsis, which is a life-threatening condition that can cause organ failure.
3. Unstable T11 fracture: The patient has an unstable T11 fracture, which can cause spinal cord injury and can be a source of pain.
4. Autonomic lability and hypotension: The patient has autonomic lability and hypotension, which can be caused by a variety of factors, including pain, sepsis, and medication.
5. Leukocytosis: The patient has leukocytosis, which is a common complication of sepsis.
6. Diabetes mellitus: The patient has diabetes mellitus, which can increase her risk of developing complications such as sepsis and pneumonia.
7. Anemia: The patient has anemia, which can be caused by a variety of factors, including blood loss, infection, and medication.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Pneumonia: The patient's history of COPD and pneumonia increases her risk of developing further respiratory complications.
2. Sepsis: The patient's diagnosis of sepsis increases her risk of developing further organ failure.
3. Unstable T11 fracture: The patient's unstable T11 fracture increases her risk of developing spinal cord injury and can cause further pain.

5. Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis can increase her risk of developing further complications, such as sepsis and organ failure.
6. Diabetes mellitus: The patient's diabetes mellitus increases her risk of developing further complications, such as sepsis and pneumonia.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia can increase her risk of developing further complications, such as bleeding and infection.

In conclusion, the patient is a complex case with multiple medical complications and potential complications. She requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications and to improve her overall outcome.

   This is a 76 year old female with a history of COPD on home oxygen (2L
   baseline), mild aortic stenosis and diastolic heart failure who
   presented to [**Location (un) 1415**] on [**2119-12-30**] with progressive dyspnea on exertion
   and cough productive of clear sputum transferred here after PEA arrest
   with evidence of unstable T11 fracture. Cord injury very likely, very
   poor surgical candidate. After discussing with family, will hold on any
   surgical intervention for spine. Now sputum with coag + staph and
   (likely contaminant) coag
 in blood culture.
   Shortness of breath/Hypercarbic respiratory failure
   Patient with known COPD at baseline on home oxygen. Trial of MMV on
   [**1-3**] resulted in no spontaneous breathing. Thererfore will check gas
   and if acceptable continue present pressure support for now, despite
   short apneic periods.  Will reduce FiO2 to 30%. Continue but reduce
   steroids for COPD, continue linezolid and cefepime given sputum
   culture. Also continue nebs. CXR stable to improved yesterday.
   Breathing stable to improved.  Little response per RT with nebs and
   fluid balance up by more than 8 liters over stay (here
 perhaps more
   including [**Location (un) 1415**]).  Given pseudomonas and MRSA in sputum
 have to
   cover for SA pneumonia and previous UTI (cefepime now covering)
   - Continue CMV
 reduce FiO2 to 30%
   - Diurese gently with goal of -500 mL to see if respiratory status
   improves further (continue steroids and antibiotics as are for now
   given changing fluid status today and desire to keep her in good shape
   for surgery)
   - Discuss ventilation/respiratory status with anesthesia to see if they
   feel that surgery possible tomorrow.
   - Solumedrol to 40 mg IV Q8H
   - Continue albuterol and ipratropium
   - Continue cefepime, linezolid (vancomycin results in desquamative
   reaction) (for 8d course started on [**1-2**]).
   Unstable T11 fracture
   Ortho. Spine will be able to operate tomorrow.  We will continue to
   maximize respiratory status for surgery.  No MI despite PEA arrest, but
   originally not as clear and Anesthesia
s decision partly based on risk
   associated with recent MI.  Therefore she may not be very far from
   baseline risk at the present time given near baseline echo, no
   significant enzyme leak.  We will discuss ventilating her in prone
   position with recently dislocated shoulder with Anesthesia.

 unknown etiology.  DM, CMV, pain (some not
